revision.text:
{{See also|Winter of 2009–2010 in Great Britain and Ireland}} {{See also|2010 Swedish cold waves}} {{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox winter storm |name=Winter of 2009–2010 in Europe |image location= Europe Temperature Map 2009-12.png |image name= Map of Europe showing the difference of temperature between 11–18 December 2009 and the 2000–2008 average. |alt= |date formed=16 December 2009 |maximum amount= {{convert|115|cm}} on 25 February in [[Kvam]], [[Norway]]{{cite news|url=http://www.yr.no/observasjonar/1.4276285|title=Snødybder|date=25 February 2010|publisher=yr.no|accessdate=25 February 2010}} |lowest temperature = {{convert|-45.6|°C|1}} in
[[Folldal]], [[Norway]]{{cite news|url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/hedmark_og_oppland/1.6934957|title=- 45,6 i Folldal|date=7 January 2010|publisher=[[NRK]]|accessdate=7 January 2010|first=Vibecke Wold|last=Haagensen|language=Norwegian}} |total fatalities=> 310 |stormtype=Winter storm |pressure= |areas affected=Most of Europe }} The '''winter of 2009–2010 in Europe''' was unusually cold. Globally, unusual weather patterns brought cold, moist air from the north. Weather systems were undergoing [[cyclogenesis]] from North American storms moving across the Atlantic Ocean to the west, and saw many parts of Europe experiencing heavy snowfall and record-low temperatures. This led to a number of deaths, widespread transport disruption, power failures and postponed sporting events. =={{anchor|Causes}}Cause== The cold weather was caused by high pressure over [[Greenland]] and [[Iceland]] forcing weather patterns southward, a phenomenon described by meteorologists as the [[Arctic Oscillation]] and also the [[North Atlantic Oscillation]] which were negative compared to normal.{{citation| url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/weather/article6982249.ece| title= Life in the deep freeze| work = www.timesonline.co.uk|date = 10 January 2010| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110604144717/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/weather/article6982249.ece| archivedate =4 June 2011 |author = Richard Woods}} The [[North Atlantic Oscillation]] in Winter 2009/10 was lower than during any winter in over a century and this resulted in more easterly winds bringing cold air into Northern Europe from Siberia and the Arctic. Scientists have shown that [[El Niño]], the [[Quasi-Biennial Oscillation]]{{citation| url = http://iopscience.iop.org/1748-9326/7/3/034031| title= Seasonal Forecasts of northern hemisphere winter 2009/10|date = 10 January 2010|author = D. Fereday, A. Maidens, A. Arribas, A.A. Scaife and J.R. Knight}} and [[solar variation|solar variability]] all conspired to drive this extreme winter. =={{anchor|Timeline}}December 2009== ==={{anchor|16–19 December|20 December|21 December}}16–21 December=== [[File:Paris France December 17.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.75|Paris, 17 December 2009|alt=Gray, snowy aerial view of Paris]] Light snowfall occurred in the UK on 16 December and weather warnings were given on most local TV stations; there were some traffic jams towards the south. The snow later spread towards France and northern Spain. In mainland Europe, early snowfall was seen across much of the western half of the continent. On 17 December, the Swiss canton of [[Grisons]] saw a record-low overnight temperature of −32 °C (−25.6 °F). This snowfall led to the shutdown of [[Utrecht Centraal]] (the largest rail hub in the Netherlands). While snowfall on highways led to the busiest morning rush hour of 2009, with a total of 671 km (417 m) in traffic jams.{{cite news|url = http://www.depers.nl/binnenland/361576/Drukste-ochtendspits-van-het-jaar.html|title= Drukste ochtendspits van het jaar|publisher= De Pers|date = 17 December 2009|accessdate= 21 December 2009}} The following day, heavy overnight [[snowfall]] caused widespread disruption across large parts of the [[South East England|South East]], [[East Anglia]], the [[East Midlands]] and [[Yorkshire and the Humber]] in Britain. This snow was in the north half of a depression with east winds centred south of England. Several deaths attributed to the cold weather were reported.{{cite news|url= https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5gV8Rxf2WHME7XwVV0USEblrKvHxQ|title= Subfreezing weather batters Europe, causing deaths and travel havoc|publisher= The Canadian Press|first= Vanessa|last= Gera|date= 20 December 2009|accessdate= 20 December 2009}} During the night of 18–19 December, five [[Eurostar]] trains were stuck in the [[Channel Tunnel]], trapping more than 2,000 people for up to 16 hours after the vehicles suffered electrical failures because of freezing overnight temperatures. Passengers were without heating, lighting and [[air-conditioning]] for several hours while food and water ran out.{{cite news|url= http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/World/Story/STIStory_468802.html|title= Cold snap lashes Europe|publisher= The Straites Times|date= 20 December 2009|accessdate= 20 December 2009}} Some passengers were evacuated via service tunnels to car trains, while others were kept on their trains until the trains could be towed out.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8421875.stm|title= Thousands freed from Channel Tunnel after trains fail|publisher= BBC News|date= 19 December 2009|accessdate= 19 December 2009}} Eurostar added special services on the evening of 19 December to transport "vulnerable passengers" between London, Paris and Brussels. However, a service from Paris became the sixth train to break down after becoming stuck near [[Ebbsfleet International railway station|Ebbsfleet]], Kent.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8422978.stm|title= Eurostar train becomes stranded on way from Paris|publisher= BBC News|date= 19 December 2009|accessdate= 19 December 2009}} The cause of the breakdowns was unclear; Eurostar initially blamed the sudden contrast between freezing temperatures above ground and the {{convert|25|C}} heat of the tunnel, which affected the high-speed engines.{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2009/dec/20/eurostar-suspended-cold-snap|title= Snow brings travel chaos across UK as Eurostar trains suspended|publisher= Guardian.co.uk|first= Matthew|last= Wainwright|date= 20 December 2009|accessdate= 20 December 2009 | location=London}} On 20 December in the [[Netherlands]], the Royal Dutch Meteorological Institute ([[KNMI (institute)|KNMI]]) issued an official weather alarm for the entire country following heavy snowfall ({{convert|15|-|20|cm|disp=or|abbr=on}}) in the west, which eventually spread to the entire country. In most cities bus services were halted and tram service was halted in all four major cities. In northern Italy several locations recorded the lowest temperatures since 1985, with one low reaching −17 °C (1.4 °F).{{cite news|url= http://www.meteogiornale.it/notizia/16901-1-il-gelo-del-20-dicembre-2009-e-gia-storia|title=Il gelo del 20 dicembre 2009 è già storia |date= 21 December 2009|accessdate= 21 December 2009}} [[File:Wroclaw snow 09.jpg|thumb|left|[[Wrocław]], Poland, 20 December 2009|alt=Aerial view of snowy Wrocław, Poland]] Police in Poland reported that 15 people froze to death in the country as overnight temperatures fell as low as {{convert|-20|C}} and 47 people died indirectly as a result of the cold during the month of December. Public appeals were made to the Polish community to report any homeless or drunk people lying outdoors, in an attempt to reduce the number of deaths from exposure to the cold.{{cite news|url= https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5gV8Rxf2WHME7XwVV0USEblrKvHxQ|title= 15 people die as temperatures fall far below freezing|publisher= The Canadian Press|date= 20 December 2009|accessdate= 20 December 2009}} In [[Kosovo]], one person died and ten people were injured in traffic accidents because of poor weather conditions. [[Kosovo Police]] spokesperson, Arbër Beka, said that one person died in an accident which occurred near [[Đakovica]]; there were injuries reported in 16 traffic accidents, and a total of 74 accidents causing property damage. The local police called on residents to be careful on the roads because of the heavy snowfall and very difficult driving conditions.[http://www.b92.net/eng/news/society-article.php?yyyy=2009&mm=12&dd=20&nav_id=63886 "Weather causes problems in Kosovo"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606111143/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/society-article.php?yyyy=2009&mm=12&dd=20&nav_id=63886 |date=6 June 2011 }} ''[[B92]]'' 20 December 2009; retrieved 20 December 2009 On 21 December, the [[M25 motorway]] and large parts of the [[M3 motorway (Great Britain)|M3]], [[M4 motorway|M4]], [[M40 motorway|M40]], [[M1 motorway|M1]] and [[M11 motorway|M11]] motorways in the United Kingdom were brought to a standstill until late at night and many towns were gridlocked. About 100 people were able to travel from [[London Victoria Station]] to [[Ashford International railway station]] on a [[steam locomotive|steam train]] hauled by the locomotive [[LNER Peppercorn Class A1 60163 Tornado|''Tornado'']].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/8428097.stm |title=Steam train's snow rescue 'glory' |publisher=BBC News Online |accessdate=23 December 2009 | date=23 December 2009}} Widespread transport disruption affected parts of England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland (except a few southern parts of [[Munster]]).{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8424338.stm|title= Cold weather causes travel disruption across the UK|publisher= BBC News|date= 21 December 2009|accessdate= 21 December 2009}} In [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], three people were found dead from [[hypothermia]] in [[Sarajevo]] and [[Teslić]].[http://www.b92.net/eng/news/region-article.php?yyyy=2009&mm=12&dd=21&nav_id=63926 "Three people freeze to death in Bosnia"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100116082104/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/region-article.php?yyyy=2009&mm=12&dd=21&nav_id=63926 |date=16 January 2010 }} ''B92'' 21 December 2009; retrieved 21 December 2009 {{Clear}} ==={{anchor|22 December|23 December|24 December|25 December|26 December}}22–26 December=== Fresh overnight snowfall brought renewed problems to parts of the United Kingdom. Particularly badly hit were north [[Hampshire]] and the [[Thames Valley]] in England. In [[Basingstoke]], some 3,000 motorists were forced to either abandon their vehicles or sleep in them overnight after becoming stuck in gridlocked traffic; approximately 2,000 cars were abandoned.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8425718.stm|title= Thousands trapped in cars overnight because of snow and ice|publisher= BBC News|date= 22 December 2009|accessdate= 23 December 2009}} The vehicle recovery service, [[The Automobile Association|AA]], accused some local authorities of not acting quickly enough to grit the roads, claiming some "key roads" had "not been gritted at all". The [[Local Government Association]] dismissed the claims as "unverified, unsubstantiated and unjustified". A man found unconscious in his back garden on the [[Isle of Lewis]], in the [[Outer Hebrides]], after a night out over the weekend died.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/highlands_and_islands/8425781.stm|title= Man, 35, found in his garden dies |publisher=BBC News Online|date=22 December 2009|accessdate= 22 December 2009}} A homeless charity in France reported that 12 people died during December as a result of the severe cold.{{cite news|url= https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5BL28620091222|title= Eurostar trains resume, snow slows Europe travel|publisher= Reuters|date= 22 December 2009|accessdate= 22 December 2009}} On 23 December, overnight temperatures in the UK once again dropped well below freezing. [[Dalwhinnie]] in the central [[Scottish Highlands|Highlands]] of Scotland recorded a low of {{convert|-16|C}} and [[Edinburgh]] recorded {{convert|-10|C}}, causing [[Minister for Transport, Infrastructure and Climate Change|Scottish Transport Minister]] [[Stewart Stevenson]] to state that conditions on Scottish roads were at their worst in 20 years.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8427781.stm|title= Christmas getaway weather problems continue|publisher= BBC News|date= 23 December 2009|accessdate= 23 December 2009}} Air travel was disrupted in the United Kingdom, with [[Southampton Airport]] cancelling (or diverting) all inbound and outbound flights until midday due to a frozen runway. Train services were cancelled for most of the day from [[Southampton Airport Parkway railway station|Southampton Airport Parkway]]. A [[Ryanair]] flight landing at [[Prestwick Airport]] overshot the runway; no injuries were reported and the airport was soon reopened.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/glasgow_and_west/8427830.stm|title= Aircraft slides off end of runway|publisher= BBC News|date= 23 December 2009|accessdate= 23 December 2009}} Two women were killed and more than 40 people injured following a coach crash on an ungritted country road in Cornwall, as a party returned from a trip to see Christmas lights in [[Mousehole]] the previous evening.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/cornwall/8427599.stm|title= Coach crash in Cornwall leaves two dead and 47 injured|publisher= BBC News|date= 23 December 2009|accessdate= 23 December 2009}}{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8429346.stm|title= Festive getaway passes 'smoothly' on UK roads|publisher= BBC News|date= 24 December 2009|accessdate= 24 December 2009}} Weather forecasters warned of icy conditions and further snowfall into Christmas Eve, particularly affecting northern England and the East Midlands. In western [[Serbia]], rapidly melting snow caused the [[Jadar (Drina)|Jadar River]] in [[Loznica]] to flood and resulted in farmland being submerged. Danijela Despotović, of the Hydro-Meteorological Service of Serbia in Loznica, said that the temperature was {{convert|-19|C}} in the town.[http://www.b92.net/eng/news/society-article.php?yyyy=2009&mm=12&dd=23&nav_id=63975 "Temperature swing causes flooding"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606111301/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/society-article.php?yyyy=2009&mm=12&dd=23&nav_id=63975 |date=6 June 2011 }} ''B92'' 23 December 2009; accessed 23 December 2009 Heavy snowfall began in [[Saint Petersburg]], Russia. By 26 December the city was under 35 cm of snow, creating the largest December snowfall recorded in the city since 1881.{{cite news|url= http://en.rian.ru/russia/20091226/157384463.html|title= Snowstorm in St. Petersburg causes delay of 14 flights|publisher= RIA Novosti|date= 26 December 2009|accessdate= 11 January 2009}} [[File:Lockerbie, Scotland, 25 December 2009.jpg|thumb|[[Lockerbie]], [[Scotland]], 25 December 2009|alt=Snow-covered rooftops in Lockerbie, Scotland]] On Christmas Day, parts of Britain had a [[White Christmas (weather)|White Christmas]] for the first time since 2004 after snow fell in northern and central Scotland and parts of England (including [[Nottinghamshire]]). A man in [[Leeds]], West Yorkshire, froze to death after spending 24 hours in his car.{{cite news|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1238128/Britain-wakes-white-Christmas-places-least.html?ITO=1490|title= Britain enjoys a white Christmas (in some places at least)|publisher= Mail Online|date= 25 December 2009|accessdate= 25 December 2009 | location=London|first1=Arthur|last1=Martin|first2=Tom|last2=Kelly|first3=Scott|last3=Warren}} A total of 21 people were reported to have died during the cold spell in the UK [[The Netherlands]] had its first white Christmas since 1981.{{cite news|url= http://www.knmi.nl/cms/content/26607/witte_kerst_in_nederland|title= (Dutch) Witte kerst in Nederland|publisher= KNMI|date= 26 December 2009|accessdate= 25 December 2009}} On 26 December ([[Boxing Day]]), drivers in Northern Ireland were warned of icy conditions.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/8430791.stm|title= Motorists warned to take care on icy roads in NI|publisher= BBC News|date= 26 December 2009|accessdate= 26 December 2009}} Conditions in many other parts of the UK continued to improve as milder air moved in from the south. However, northern England and Scotland remained cold and nighttime temperatures continued to drop below freezing. Some [[Boxing Day]] sporting fixtures were cancelled (or postponed) because of continuing icy conditions in certain areas, including the [[National Hunt racing|National Hunt meeting]] at [[Towcester]] and all but two of the [[Scottish Football League]]'s matches. Some parts of [[East Anglia]] suffered electricity cuts, including [[Dedham, Essex|Dedham]], [[Stratford St Mary]] and parts of [[Colchester]]; in more remote parts of the region, some were without power for 36 hours.{{cite web|url=http://www.electric.co.uk/news/tag/power-cuts |title=Power Cuts |publisher=Electric.co.uk |date= |accessdate=9 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090819205616/http://www.electric.co.uk/news/tag/power-cuts |archivedate=19 August 2009 |df= }}{{cite web|author=Herts Advertiser |url=http://www.hertsad.co.uk/content/herts/news/story.aspx?brand=HADOnline&category=News&tBrand=HertsCambsOnline&tCategory=newslatestHAD&itemid=WEED24+Dec+2009+12%3A42%3A30%3A880 |title=Wheathampstead Power Cuts Are "Not Acceptable" |publisher=Herts Advertiser|date=24 December 2009 |accessdate= 9 January 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://islington-libdems.org.uk/news/000772/power_cuts_in_hillrise.html |title=Power cuts in Hillrise (Islington Liberal Democrats) |publisher=Islington Liberal Democrats|date=4 November 2003|accessdate=9 January 2010}} ==={{anchor|28 December|29 December|30 December|31 December}}27–31 December=== Parts of England again suffered power cuts on 26–27 December. Scotland experienced fresh snowfall overnight; [[Perthshire]] being the most-affected area, where between {{convert|12|and(-)|18|in|cm}} fell.{{cite news|url= http://www.pressandjournal.co.uk/Article.aspx/1540191?UserKey=|title= Roads havoc as temperature plummets|publisher= Press and Journal|first= Catriona|last= Webster|date= 28 December 2009|accessdate= 28 December 2009}} Temperatures fell to {{convert|-16|C}} in [[Tyndrum]] overnight on 27–28 December, and to {{convert|-14|C}} at Tulloch Bridge in the Highlands. The [[Met Office]] issued fresh [[severe weather warning]]s and motorists were advised to drive with caution. The [[A75 road (Great Britain)|A75]] between [[Stranraer]] and [[Newton Stewart]] was closed due to icy conditions; while the southbound carriageway of the [[A9 road (Great Britain)|A9]] was blocked between the A824 and B8081 in [[Perth and Kinross]] following an accident at [[Gleneagles, Scotland|Gleneagles]].{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/8432460.stm|title= Ice alert as temperatures plunge to −16C|publisher= BBC News|date= 28 December 2009|accessdate= 28 December 2009}} Temperatures dropped to {{convert|-18|C}} in parts of the Highlands overnight on 28–29 December, with [[Braemar]] recording Britain's lowest temperature of the Winter. Fresh travel warnings were issued on 29 December, as wintry conditions continued to cause problems on Scotland's roads. The runway of [[Inverness Airport]] was briefly closed because of snow and ice, and [[First ScotRail]] reduced its service to and from [[Glasgow Central railway station|Glasgow Central]] because of the severe conditions. However, the snow and icy conditions were good for the Scottish [[ski]] industry, which said the weather helped it to experience its best start to the season for several years.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/8432460.stm|title= Travel warnings issued over wintry conditions|publisher= BBC News|date= 29 December 2009|accessdate= 30 December 2009}} Warnings of heavy snow were issued for Wales, the Midlands, Yorkshire and Humber, north-west England, eastern and southern England.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8432437.stm|title= Snow hits Wales and the Midlands with more to come|publisher= BBC News|date= 29 December 2009|accessdate= 31 December 2009}} More snow began falling across parts of Wales/central and northern England on the evening of 29 December, with Wales recording the heaviest of the snow showers; some rural areas recording up to {{convert|30|cm}}. Snow was also reported in parts of the [[West Midlands (region)|West Midlands region]] and [[Yorkshire]]. On 30 December, [[Sportscotland Avalanche Information Service]] (SAIS) issued warnings about conditions on Scottish mountains. However, three people died in three large avalanches.{{cite news|url= https://www.google.com/hostednews/ukpress/article/ALeqM5goM5jhhBUYkvn5NImh-lWgObRy8A|title= Three climbers die in avalanches|publisher= The Press Association|date= 30 December 2009|accessdate= 30 December 2009}} Two climbers were killed as a result of a snow slide on [[Ben Nevis]], while a man was airlifted from [[Liathach]] (a mountain in [[Torridon]]) after getting into trouble, but died in hospital.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/highlands_and_islands/8434825.stm|title= Three climbers die in avalanches|publisher= BBC News|date= 30 December 2009|accessdate= 30 December 2009}} Continued icy weather in Scotland on New Year's Eve led to the cancellation of [[Hogmanay]] celebrations in [[Inverness]], amid concerns over public safety;{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/8435378.stm|title= Snow forces cancellation of Inverness Hogmanay party|publisher= BBC News|date= 31 December 2009|accessdate= 31 December 2009}} New Year celebrations in other parts of Scotland went ahead as planned. Northeast Scotland experienced fresh snowfall during the afternoon and evening of 31 December. For a second time that week [[Inverness Airport]] was closed, forcing several hundred passengers to make alternative arrangements. In [[Batley]], West Yorkshire, 2,500 gallons of water leaked into the local gas network; 400 homes in [[Dewsbury]] and Batley were without gas during subzero temperatures. The final homes were reconnected on 7 January.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bradford/8439048.stm|title= Hundreds without gas after flood|publisher= BBC News|date= 4 January 2010|accessdate= 7 January 2010}} There was also heavy snowfall in Dublin, Ireland, leading to the closure of Dublin Airport for several hours disrupting flights.{{cite news|url= https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE60002120100101|title= Dublin Airport suspends flights in cold weather|publisher= Reuters|date= 1 January 2010|accessdate= 1 January 2010 | first=Andras | last=Gergely}} In [[Dublin]], the snow began 10 minutes before the New Year's Eve countdown. ==January 2010== ==={{anchor|1 January|2 January|3 January|4 January|5 January}}1–5 January=== Fresh overnight snowfall on New Year's Eve and New Year's Day caused disruption in [[North East England]], Cumbria and the [[Scottish Borders]]. In some places it was as deep as {{convert|10|cm}}, and motorists were warned not to travel unless absolutely necessary.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/8436969.stm|title= Heavy snow prompts travel warning in North East|publisher= BBC News|date= 1 January 2010|accessdate= 1 January 2010}} On 2 January, the synoptic position settled with the [[jet stream]] in a route causing a [[blocking high]] in the eastern Atlantic. This diverted warm west winds to the south over the Mediterranean and subjected western Europe to cold north winds, warm weather around the [[Caspian Sea]] and unusually cold weather in China. A weather front brought heavy snow to [[north west England]]. In Britain many roads were closed, including part of the [[M9 motorway (Scotland)|M9]].{{cite news|url=http://news.stv.tv/scotland/147689-widespread-problems-on-scotlands-roads-as-cold-spell-continues/ |title=Widespread problems on Scotland's roads as cold spell continues |publisher=STV |first=Graham |last=Fraser |date=2 January 2010 |accessdate=2 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100117195607/http://news.stv.tv/scotland/147689-widespread-problems-on-scotlands-roads-as-cold-spell-continues/ |archivedate=17 January 2010 |df= }} [[File:Antwerp, belgium January 3.jpg|thumb|upright=0.75|[[Antwerp]], [[Belgium]], 3 January 2010|alt=Snow-covered Antwerp, with government buildings in the background against a blue sky]] On 3 January parts of northeast England and [[Cumbria]] had {{convert|6|cm}} of snow, and Edinburgh had {{convert|9|cm}}.{{cite news|url= http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Weather-Motorists-Warned-Of-Icy-Roads-And-Snowfall-In-North-England-And-Scotland/Article/201001115513482?lpos=UK_News_Top_Stories_Header_4&lid=ARTICLE_15513482_Weather%3A_Motorists_Warned_Of_Icy_Roads_And_Snowfall_In_North_England_And_Scotland|title= Motorists Face An Icy Return To Work|publisher= Sky News Online|first= Ruth|last= Barnett|date= 3 January 2010|accessdate= 3 January 2010}} Europe's largest private-sector weather business, [[MeteoGroup]], announced that the previous month was the coldest December (on average) since 1996.{{cite news|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/topics/weather/6925487/Snow-continues-to-cause-chaos-across-Britain.html|title= Snow continues to cause chaos across Britain|publisher= Telegraph.co.uk|date= 2 January 2010|accessdate= 3 January 2010 | location=London}} Temperatures remained very cold throughout Ireland and Britain;{{cite news|url= https://www.google.com/hostednews/ukpress/article/ALeqM5j81Fm5NwsIVBzCwuZMCXhPPjIauA|title= More snow set to blanket Britain|publisher= The Press Association|date= 3 January 2010|accessdate= 3 January 2010}} however, Inverness Airport reopened after several days.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/highlands_and_islands/8436767.stm|title= Flights take off at weather-hit airport|publisher= BBC News|date= 3 January 2010|accessdate= 3 January 2010}} It was announced that due to the cold snap, it would be illegal to shoot certain [[game bird]]s. An all-time snow record in the Estonian capital, [[Tallinn]], was measured at 62 cm (two feet).{{cite news|url= http://www.ilm.ee/index.php?46813|title= Tallinnas registreeriti lumerekord|date= 3 January 2010|language=et}} The next day in Scotland, [[Fife]] Council became the first local council to confirm that its supplies of grit were exhausted after it received less than it had ordered from suppliers. Ministers denied there was a shortage of grit and salt, insisting there were "very substantial" supplies for Scotland's roads.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/8438717.stm|title= Ministers deny salt supply crisis|publisher= BBC News|date= 4 January 2010|accessdate= 5 January 2010}} In its monthly summary ''Met Éireann'', Ireland's weather service, said December was the coldest month for 28 years for most of the country and the coldest of any month since February 1986 at several stations.{{cite news|url= http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/0104/breaking26.html?via=rel|title= December was coldest month in 28 years|publisher= Irish Times|date= 4 January 2010|accessdate= 4 January 2010}} Wintry conditions returned to Europe, as much of the [[northern hemisphere]] was gripped by intensely cold weather.{{cite news|url= http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/weather/article6975867.ece|title= Arctic freeze and snow wreak havoc across the planet|publisher= Times Online|date= 5 January 2010|accessdate= 5 January 2010 | location=London | first1=Charles | last1=Bremner}} 13 people died in Poland, bringing the total number of cold-related deaths in Poland to 122. In [[Switzerland]], ten skiers were reported dead or missing in [[avalanche]]s. The worst incident occurred in the [[Diemtig Valley]]; avalanches hit a group of skiers and their rescuers, killing four people (including a doctor). Eight people were rescued, although three remained missing. On 5 January, the [[Met Office]] issued weather warnings for every region in the UK except the [[Northern Isles]]. An extreme-weather warning was issued in the southern areas for overnight snowfall, which could bring accumulations from {{convert|25|to|40|cm|in}}.{{cite news|url= http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article6976571.ece|title= Met Office warns of 40 cm of snow within hours in South East|publisher= Times Online|date= 5 January 2010|accessdate= 5 January 2010 | location=London | first1=Nico | last1=Hines | first2=Simon | last2=de Bruxelles | first3=Charlene | last3=Sweeney}} BBC Weather and the Met Office also warned that temperatures in the Highlands of Scotland could drop to {{convert|-20|C|F}} later in the week. The Met Office also confirmed that the UK is experiencing the longest prolonged cold spell since 1981. {{convert|48|cm}} of snow fell in [[Aviemore]], Scotland, and {{convert|3|to|4|ft}} of snow was recorded within the Cairngorms National Park. Most of Scotland had further snowfall during the night of 4–5 January. ==={{anchor|6 January|7 January|Trains|Other|8 January|9 January}}6–9 January=== [[File:Hamburg Germany Jan 6.jpg|thumb|left|[[Port of Hamburg]], Germany, 6 January 2010|alt=Ships in snowy Hamburg, Germany harbour]] The synoptic situation in northern Europe settled into a steady northeast wind, which brought snow showers and belts of snow. The [[British Armed Forces|British Army]] had to help stranded motorists in southern areas.{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-01-06/army-rescues-u-k-drivers-as-snow-snarls-transport-update2-.html |title=Army Rescues U.K. Drivers as Snow Snarls Transport (Update2) |publisher=Bloomberg News |date=6 January 2010 |accessdate=6 January 2010 |first=Alex |last=Morales |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100110005019/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-01-06/army-rescues-u-k-drivers-as-snow-snarls-transport-update2-.html |archivedate=10 January 2010 }} The Met Office confirmed that {{convert|40|cm}} of snow fell in some parts of southern England.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8444399.stm|title= Severe weather continues to grip the UK and cause havoc|publisher= BBC News|date= 6 January 2010|accessdate= 6 January 2010}} A severe warning issued by the [[Met Office]] was in place for every region in the UK.{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} Scottish [[First Minister of Scotland|First Minister]] [[Alex Salmond]] said Scotland was experiencing its worst winter since [[Winter of 1962–1963 in the United Kingdom|1963]]. Further deaths in Wales, Shetland and Aberdeenshire were recorded. [[Hawick]] and most of the southern Scottish Borders was cut off from the rest of the country for two days,{{cite news|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/uk/lack+of+grit+isolates+hawick/3490962|title=Lack of grit isolates Hawick|publisher= Channel 4|date= 7 January 2010}} and roads in the southeast of England were left with traffic jams and abandoned cars. 8,000 schools were closed.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8442739.stm|title= Schools closed and travellers hit as snow continues|publisher= BBC News|date= 6 January 2010|accessdate= 7 January 2010}} [[File:Great Britain Snowy.jpg|thumb|upright|Satellite picture showing extent of snow cover across Great Britain and Ireland on 7 January|alt=A satellite photo of Great Britain and Ireland. Great Britain is white as a result of snow cover and Ireland is mostly green with some snow cover in the east. Cloud is scatted across the surrounding sea and eastern Ireland, as well as the east coast of Great Britain (especially the southeast).]] The lowest registered temperature on 7 January in Sweden was {{convert|-40.8|C}} in [[Hemavan]].{{cite web|author=Sveriges Radio |url=http://www.sr.se/ekot/artikel.asp?artikel=3355115 |title=Ekot news |publisher=Sr.se |date= |accessdate=9 January 2010}} In the Netherlands and Belgium, road salt used to keep the roads clear of snow and ice was running out.{{cite news|url= http://www.elsevier.nl/web/Nieuws/Nederland/255161/Strooizouttekort-dreigt-Van-der-Hoeven-schiet-te-hulp.htm|title= Strooizouttekort dreigt; Van der Hoeven schiet te hulp (Dutch)|publisher= Elsevier|date= 7 January 2010|accessdate= 7 January 2010}} National and secondary schools in Ireland were supposed to open after the Christmas break on this day; however, many were forced to close because of weather conditions. On 8 January, the Minister for Education announced that all schools were to remain closed until at least Thursday, 14 January.{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0108/educationweather.html |title=RTÉ News: All schools to close until Thursday |publisher=RTÉ|date= |accessdate=9 January 2010}} On the [[Luas]] [[Green Line (Luas)|Green line]] there were difficulties getting up slopes, such as those between [[Harcourt Street railway station|Harcourt]] and Charlemont and between [[Beechwood]] and Cowper. This had caused some delays (especially when salt was scarce for sand tanks on the trams) for [[Dublin]] pedestrians. Major [[reservoirs]] in [[County Cork]], [[County Dublin]] and [[County Limerick]] were critically low; in areas such as [[County Laois]] and the rural areas of County Cork, bottled water was supplied by the Irish army. This had also been done for the people affected by floods in October and November 2009. The [[National Grid (UK)|National Grid]] issued its second alert in three days, asking suppliers to provide more gas and some businesses to switch to other power sources, as gas usage hit record levels.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8446487.stm|title= Gas usage set to hit new record|publisher= BBC News|date= 7 January 2010|accessdate= 7 January 2010}} [[BBC News]] reported heavy snowfall as far south as [[Granada]], Spain on 8 January.{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} A new record of {{convert|-9|C}} was also recorded in [[Dublin]], Ireland. Temperatures in County [[Limerick]] dropped to {{convert|-11.1|C}}. In [[Kuusamo]], Finland, the lowest registered temperature was {{convert|-37.1|C}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.hs.fi/kotimaa/artikkeli/1135251983884|title=Kuusamossa talven uusi pakkasennätys|author=[[Suomen Tietotoimisto|STT]]|date=8 January 2010 |accessdate=8 January 2010|publisher=[[Helsingin Sanomat]]|language=Finnish}} In Norway, the temperature dropped to {{convert|-42.4|C}} at [[Tynset]].[http://www.yr.no/place/Norway/Hedmark/Tynset/Tynset~186990/statistics.html Tynset, Norway weather statistics] In Germany more than {{convert|30|cm}} of snow fell on the island of [[Rügen]], and the entire country was blanketed in snow. German officials also acknowledged a shortage of grit, and feared that high winds and drifting snow would lead to road closures.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8448095.stm |title=Germany prepares to face blizzard |publisher=BBC News |date=8 January 2010 |accessdate=9 January 2010}} In France, officials closed [[A35 autoroute|Autoroute 35]] for trucks because of heavy snow, and over 400 truck drivers bound for Germany had to make an unscheduled overnight stop. In the early morning hours of 9 January, the ''autoroute'' was also closed to cars. The storm also grounded 160 flights at the [[Frankfurt am Main]] international airport.{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/0,1518,670947,00.html |title=400 Fahrer verbringen eisige Nacht an der Grenze|publisher=Spiegel Online|date= 9 January 2010|accessdate=9 January 2010}} Snow fell heavily in some parts of Spain. Prades (Tarragona, southern Catalonia) sported a 120 cm snow cover after a 30-plus- hour storm,{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} which led to an 18-hour closure of the AP7 motorway at La Jonquera (at the Spanish/French border).{{cite web|url=http://www.rtve.es/noticias/20100108/nieve-mantiene-cortadas-siete-carreteras-red-principal-puerto-san-glorio/310595.shtml |title=La nieve mantiene cortadas siete carreteras de la red principal y el puerto de San Glorio|publisher=Radio y Televisión Española |date= |accessdate=8 January 2010}} Overnight temperatures of {{convert|-22.3|C}} were recorded in [[Altnaharra]] in the [[Scottish Highlands]].{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/topics/weather/6949626/Big-freeze-ice-warning-as-temperatures-hit-winter-low-of--22.3hC.html|title=Big freeze: ice warning as temperatures hit winter low of −22.3hC|last=Adams|first=Stephen|date=8 January 2010|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|accessdate=9 January 2010 | location=London}} [[Deal, Kent|Deal]] and [[Sandwich, Kent|Sandwich]] in Kent, England, were virtually cut off by snowdrifts on 9 January.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/kent/8449956.stm |title=Heavy snow cuts off communities |publisher=BBC News Online |date=9 January 2009 |accessdate=9 January 2009}} Snow showers persisted in the east of the UK. In the far south east, snow showers merged into longer and more persistent areas of snow. A low temperature of {{convert|-14.5|°C|1}} was recorded at Tulloch Bridge. The football schedule was also heavily affected by the snowfall; all but seven games (two in both the [[Premier League]] and [[Football League One|League 1]] and three in the [[Football League Championship|Championship]]) were postponed in England, and all but five [[Scottish Cup]] games were played in Scotland. Several [[Guinness Premiership]] games and horse-racing meets were cancelled as well. {{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/front_page/8443978.stm|title=Premier League heads list of sporting postponements|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=10 February 2010 | date=9 January 2010}} Dublin Airport was closed once again.{{cite web|url=http://www.ryanair.com/ie/notices/gops/100105-SNOW_UK_05JAN10-GB |title=Snow Disruptions – 9th Jan – Update 17:00hrs |publisher=Ryanair |date=23 May 2006 |accessdate=9 January 2010}} Flights to [[Kraków]] in southern Poland were diverted to the airport in [[Katowice]], due to fog which prevented planes from landing.{{cite web|url= http://www.ryanair.com|title= Ryanair.com}} Met Éireann issued a weather warning with up to {{convert|10|cm}} of snow forecast.{{cite web|url=http://www.met.ie/forecasts/warnings.asp |title=Warnings – Met Éireann – The Irish Meteorological Service Online |publisher=Met.ie |date= |accessdate=9 January 2010}} Belgium was covered with another thick layer of snow, in some central provinces (such as [[Flemish Brabant]]) as deep as {{convert|10|cm}}. Since the snow (and possible traffic chaos) had been forecast for several days, this resulted in few people leaving their homes; traffic accidents were minor and few. At [[Brussels Airport]] slight delays were inevitable, but mostly the result of airports in neighbouring countries coping with heavier snow.{{cite web|url=http://www.deredactie.be/permalink/1.691587 |title=And the snow came from the East... |publisher=deredactie.be |language=Dutch |date=9 January 2009 |accessdate=9 January 2009}} In Denmark, army personnel carriers were once again deployed in the southern part of the country to assist emergency services as drifting continued to cause traffic problems.{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?js=y&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&layout=1&eotf=1&u=http%3A%2F%2Fpolitiken.dk%2Findland%2Farticle876833.ece&sl=da&tl=en|title=Politi sætter bæltekøretøjer ind på Falster|publisher=[[Politiken]]|date=9 January 2009 |accessdate=9 January 2009}} ==={{anchor|10 January|11 January|12–13 January|13–26 January}}10–26 January=== [[File:Alton 10 Jan.JPG|thumb|right|[[Alton, Hampshire|Alton]], England, 10 January 2010|alt=Roof icicles, as seen from upper window]] A large [[Low-pressure area|depression]] moved into the [[Western Approaches]] from the Atlantic on 10 January and began to infiltrate the coldest areas of Britain, bringing a thaw to southwest England. The weather in London cleared, allowing for transport access (particularly by road) across all areas of north and central London. A heavy snowstorm, named "Daisy", struck northern Germany on 9 and 10 January. Especially along the coast and on the islands of [[Usedom]], [[Rügen]] and [[Fehmarn]], snowdrifts made roads, parts of [[autobahn 20|the coastal autobahn]] and rail tracks impassable. In northern [[Mecklenburg-Vorpommern]] and eastern [[Schleswig-Holstein]] secondary roads were closed and trains cancelled, while snowplows and excavators struggled to keep the main routes free. Since the storms were accumulating increasingly large snowbanks, hundreds of cars were stranded on [[Bundesautobahn 20|Autobahn 20]] near [[Jarmen]] during the night, and a train derailed after striking a snowbank near [[Miltzow]].{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/0,1518,671060,00.html|title=Tief "Daisy". Rettungskräfte befreien Dutzende Autofahrer aus Schneefalle|date=10 January 2010|publisher=[[Der Spiegel|Spiegel Online]]|language=German|accessdate=10 January 2010}} In Denmark, drifting continued to disrupt traffic in the southern part of the country; army personnel carriers were used to assist emergency services.{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?js=y&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&layout=1&eotf=1&u=http%3A%2F%2Fpolitiken.dk%2Findland%2Farticle876934.ece&sl=da&tl=en|title=Snekaos breder sig til Langeland|publisher=Politiken|date=10 January 2010|accessdate=10 January 2010}} In Spain, a snowstorm swept the country; [[Madrid]] had more than 10 hours of snow. Parts of southern Spain, such as [[Seville]], saw their first snow since 1954.{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} On 11 January, England and Wales continued to feel the effects of the depression in the [[Western Approaches]]. In the Republic of Ireland, the Department of Education ordered all schools to close for the day due to heavy snowfall. Due to a mix of bitter cold and the milder system trying to push in from the [[Atlantic]], heavy snowfall in the United Kingdom resumed; there were fresh accumulations (on top of existing snow) of up to 15 centimetres (6 inches) on 12 January in [[Wales]] and [[South-west England]]. Snow later fell in [[English Midlands|The Midlands]] and [[South-east England]]. In [[Holmfirth]] and [[Barnsley]] in north England, [[freezing rain]] or [[Rain and snow mixed|sleet]] fell onto deep-frozen roads; this created so much [[black ice]] that some people found that the only safe way to move about on roads was by [[Gait (human)#Crawls|crawling]].[[BBC TV]] news Hospital accident and emergency units in the Sheffield, Rotherham and Barnsley areas of South Yorkshire reported being inundated by people with fractures and sprains after slipping on what one Council official in Sheffield described as the worst black ice seen in the area in living memory. Many schools were again closed across England and Wales, and there were many road accidents and closures. The [[M25 motorway]] was down to one lane between [[Leatherhead]] and [[Reigate]]; roads across southern Great Britain were untreated, wreaking havoc on commuters. [[Gatwick]] and [[Birmingham]] airports were closed, and many flights were delayed at [[Heathrow]]. During 13 January the weather system continued north, affecting much of [[Northern England]] before reaching [[Scotland]]. Parts of northern France were also affected by snowfall.{{cite news|title=More roads misery on "coldest day" |url=http://uk.news.yahoo.com/21/20100113/tuk-more-roads-misery-on-coldest-day-6323e80.html |date=13 January 2010 |newspaper=[[Press Association]] |accessdate=13 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100115115647/http://uk.news.yahoo.com/21/20100113/tuk-more-roads-misery-on-coldest-day-6323e80.html |archivedate=15 January 2010 }} At least 22 people died due to lower temperatures in [[Romania]] over a five-day period.{{cite web|url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-ultima_ora-6843711-gerul-provocat-22-decese-ultimele-cinci-zile.htm |title=Gerul a provocat 22 de decese in ultimele cinci zile – Ultima ora |publisher=HotNews.ro |date= |accessdate=15 April 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.antena3.ro/stiri/meteo/mai-frig-ca-la-polul-nord-temperaturile-din-romania-mai-scazute-ca-in-nordul-continentului_90311.html |title=Mai frig ca la Polul Nord Temperaturile din Romania mai scazute ca in Alaska |publisher=Antena3.ro |date= |accessdate=15 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100317041023/http://www.antena3.ro/stiri/meteo/mai-frig-ca-la-polul-nord-temperaturile-din-romania-mai-scazute-ca-in-nordul-continentului_90311.html |archivedate=17 March 2010 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.antena3.ro/stiri/romania/au-murit-de-frig-11-decese-din-cauza-gerului-in-ultimele-24-de-ore_90318.html |title=Au murit de frig 11 decese din cauza gerului in ultimele 24 de ore |publisher=Antena3.ro |date=25 January 2010 |accessdate=15 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100129042634/http://antena3.ro/stiri/romania/au-murit-de-frig-11-decese-din-cauza-gerului-in-ultimele-24-de-ore_90318.html |archivedate=29 January 2010 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.mediafax.ro/english/cold-weather-kills-11-people-in-romania-health-ministry-5194135 |title=Cold Weather Kills 11 People in Romania – Health Ministry – Mediafax |publisher=Mediafax |date= |accessdate=15 April 2010}} By the end of January in southern Sweden, temperatures had failed to get above {{convert|0|C|F}} a single time in the whole month in the major cities in the entire [[Mälardalen|Mälar valley]], including capital [[Stockholm]] as well as major other cities such as [[Uppsala]], [[Västerås]] and [[Örebro]]. Remarkably enough that even spread further south to inland cities in the deep south such as [[Växjö]] and [[Ljungby]].{{cite web|url=http://data.smhi.se/met/climate/time_series/month/vov_pdf/SMHI_vov_temperature_wind_jan10.pdf?84120|title=Temperature & Wind for January 2010|language=sv|publisher=SMHI|accessdate=2 November 2015}} Although temperatures were lower than usual, no actual cold records were broken, but even temperatures in marine climate areas such as in [[Malmö]] plummeted below {{convert|-15|C|F}} during the coldest nights. All of Sweden's official stations averaged below {{convert|0|C|F}} in terms of daily high, which is highly unusual. The cold in the large cities were relatively moderated, but Örebro some way inland had a {{convert|-10|C|F}} mean, which is normal for areas much further north. ==February== === 12 February === Arctic air entering the Mediterranean Sea brought snowfalls across Italian western coasts. Snow covered [[Rome]] with a couple of inches, with some flurries reaching [[Naples]]. An extremely rare snowfall occurred in [[Cagliari]], [[Sardinia]].{{citation | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0BPVtQh5oXc}}{{citation | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YFMeThIJYzI}}{{citation | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5IpZskfv1F8}} === 20 February === {{main article|2010 Madeira floods and mudslides}} At least 43 people were killed after more than a month's worth of rain fell in southern [[Madeira]] in five hours during a strong [[Atlantic]] winter storm, producing severe flooding and mudslides.{{Citation|title=Sobe para 43 o número de mortos na Madeira, já se contam mais de 100 feridos|url=http://www.publico.pt/Sociedade/sobe-para-43-o-numero-de-mortos-na-madeira_1423727|newspaper=Público}} {{Dead link|date=December 2013|bot=Theo's Little Bot}}. {{pt icon}}{{citation | url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3851935,00.html | title = Floods kill at least 32 on resort island Madeira | date = 20 February 2010 | publisher = [[Ynetnews]]}}{{citation | title = Temporal no Arquipélago da Madeira | url = http://www.meteo.pt/pt/otempo/comunicados/index.jsp | publisher = nstituto de Meteorologia, I.P. Portugal | date = 20 February 2010 | accessdate =22 February 2010|language=pt}} The unusual storm was fed by warmer-than-normal [[sea surface temperature]]s in the Northeastern Atlantic related to [[El Niño]], and a slowing of the [[North Atlantic Gyre]].{{citation | url = http://www.worldclimate.com/cgi-bin/data.pl?ref=N32W016+2100+08521W | title = Weather station FUNCHAL/S.CATARINA Average Rainfall | publisher = WorldClimate| accessdate = 22 February 2010}}{{citation | url = http://www.accuweather.com/world-news-story.asp?partner=accuweather&article=8 | title = More on Deadly Medeira Flashing Flooding | publisher = AccuWeather.com | accessdate =22 February 2010}} ===26–28 February=== {{main article|Xynthia (storm)}} At least 62 people were killed (51 in France) and 12 were missing during a [[European windstorm]] in Western Europe, affecting mainly Spain, France, Germany and the [[Benelux]] region. Numerous [[levee]]s were breached in western France. By the end of the month, the unusual cold had spread from primarily the south to the north of [[Sweden]]. Although winters of 1966 and 1985 were much colder, the average low of coastal [[Luleå]] still measured at {{convert|-21.2|C|F}} and inland more southern locality [[Lycksele]] at {{convert|-22.4|C|F}}.{{cite web|url=http://data.smhi.se/met/climate/time_series/month/vov_pdf/SMHI_vov_temperature_wind_feb10.pdf?84120|title=Temperature & Wind February 2010|language=sv|publisher=SMHI|accessdate=5 November 2015}} Further south a night low of {{convert|-29.7|C|F}} was measured in [[Gävle]] not far north of capital Stockholm. In the south, temperatures occasionally went above freezing, but average highs were firmly below freezing, except in the deep south where it hovered around the freezing point. From the beginning of March, temperatures rose to somewhat normal levels throughout the country. ==March== ===8–10 March=== {{commons category|Snowfall of 2010 in Catalonia}} [[File:Barcelona snowfall08032010.jpg|thumb|230px|[[Barcelona]] on 8 March 2010|alt=Pedestrians with umbrellas on snowy Barcelona street]] Heavy snowfall in Spain on 8 March left 220,000 people around the [[Catalonia|Catalan]] city of [[Girona]] without electricity due to a fault in a high-tension power cable. The adverse weather cut off railway lines and roads, and Spain's border with France at [[La Junquera]] was closed. Many schools cancelled classes on both 8 and 9 March.{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/mar/09/spain-snowstorms-wreak-havoc|title= Snowstorms wreak havoc in Spain|publisher= The Guardian|date= 9 March 2010|accessdate= 13 March 2010 | location=London}} The snowfall was reported to be the region's worst for 25 years,{{cite news|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/travel/article-1256549/Snow-hits-Barcelona-bringing-Catalonia-standstill.html|title= Heavy snow brings Barcelona to a standstill as trains and flights are cancelled|publisher= Mail Online|first= Joanna|last= Tweedy|date= 9 March 2010|accessdate= 13 March 2010 | location=London}} and the heaviest in [[Barcelona]] since 1962.{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gcYJgH2GjtGHJZCbXVUxd47Dhmhg|title=Snow snarls traffic, strands thousands in southern Europe|last=AFP|first=Google News|date=9 March 2010|publisher=Agence France-Presse|accessdate=18 March 2010}} The storm also dumped snow on [[Mallorca]] and the [[Balearic Islands]], causing snow and highway cancellations. Waves in the Mediterranean reached up to {{convert|7.7|m|ft|abbr=on}} and winds reached {{convert|133|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}.{{cite news|url=http://www.laht.com/article.asp?ArticleId=353529&CategoryId=12395|title=Storm Brings Snow to Spanish Tourism Mecca|last=World|first=LAHT|date=10 March 2010|publisher=Latin American Herald Tribune|accessdate=18 March 2010}} Heavy snow up to {{convert|40|cm|in|abbr=on}} fell in southern France (including [[Provence]] and the [[Pyrenees]]), forcing flight cancellations, airport and motorway closures. Over one metre of snow fell in the mountains, and numerous power outages occurred in [[Corsica]].{{cite news|url=http://www.english.rfi.fr/france/20100308-freak-snow-storm-covers-southern-france|title=Freak snow storm covers southern France|last=RFI|first=France|date=8 March 2010|publisher=RFI English|accessdate=18 March 2010}} In Greece [[dust storm]]s from the [[Sahara Desert]] reached the capital, [[Athens]], on strong southerly winds.{{cite news|url=http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/extreme-weather-hits-France-Greece|title=Extreme weather hits France and Greece|last=English|first=RNW|date=8 March 2010|work=Radio Nederland Wereldomroep|publisher=Radio Netherlands Worldwide|accessdate=18 March 2010}} The eastern end of the storm coincided with the [[2010 Elâzığ earthquake]]. ===12 March=== A snowstorm dumped over 30 centimetres of snow in southern Germany (including [[Bavaria]]), causing numerous traffic accidents and over two dozen injuries.{{cite news|url=http://www.tradingmarkets.com/news/stock-alert/bvarf_1st-ld-snowfall-causes-series-of-road-crashes-in-south-germany-841660.html|title=1st LD: Snowfall causes series of road crashes in south Germany|last=Stock Alerts|first=TradingsMarkets|date=12 March 2010|work=The Connors Group, Inc|publisher=Xinhua via COMTEX|accessdate=18 March 2010}} ===29 March – 1 April=== A massive [[snowstorm]] travelled north through the UK until it reached [[Northern Ireland]] and [[Scotland]], where it stayed for 61 hours. The [[Met Office]] issued emergency and extreme-weather warnings for Scotland and Northern Ireland for severe [[blizzard]]s, very heavy snow, heavy rain, gale-force winds, and severe drifting. On 29 March, snow began to fall heavily over Scotland and Northern Ireland; however, the 30th was far more severe, as gusts up to 80 mph brought trees down. There were accumulations of 30–60 cm of snow in Northern Ireland and Scotland; 3 ft of snow fell on [[Aviemore]]. On 31 March, a girl was killed in [[Lanarkshire]] when a [[school bus]] skidded on ice and crashed. Over 70,000 homes in Northern Ireland and Scotland were without power, and newborn [[domestic sheep|lamb]]s died in the extreme weather conditions. Thousands of cars were stranded on roads during the day; 300 cars were stranded in Northern Ireland by 5-foot [[snowdrift]]s. Strong winds brought down trees and created waves up to 20 ft. [[Travel trailer|Caravan]]s at Kingshorn were destroyed and a [[marina]] in the [[Lothians]] was bombarded and demolished by a surge of rain-driven waves. A [[seal (animal)|seal]] at St. Andrews Sea Life Centre went missing in the strong waves, and a river in [[Musselburgh]] overflowed. This snow event was the second-most disruptive of this winter in the UK. =={{anchor|Effects}}Deaths== By 7 January 2010, 22 people died in the UK because of the freezing conditions.[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/weather/article6979895.ece Deaths during Britain's big freeze] Times Online, 7 January 2010 The [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|Department of Health]] estimated that the cold weather could cause up to 40,000 excess deaths in the UK.{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10619380&pnum=2 |title=UK winter set to be the coldest in 40 years |author1=Emily Dugan, Andrew Johnson |author2=Susie Mesure |lastauthoramp=yes |date=10 January 2010 |agency=[[The Independent]] |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=4 December 2011}} 139 people died in Poland–most of them reportedly homeless.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8445613.stm |title=Airport chaos as icy weather grips northern Europe |publisher=BBC News |date= 7 January 2010|accessdate=9 January 2010}} =={{anchor|Transport}}Effects on transport== ==={{anchor|Airports|Trains|Roads and buses}}United Kingdom=== The following airports were at some point closed: [[London Gatwick Airport]], [[London Heathrow Airport]], [[Birmingham International Airport, West Midlands|Birmingham Airport]], [[Cardiff Airport]], [[London Luton Airport]], [[George Best Belfast City Airport]], [[Southampton Airport]], [[Blackpool International Airport]], [[Newcastle Airport]], [[Durham Tees Valley Airport]], [[Exeter International Airport]], [[Plymouth City Airport]] and [[London Stansted Airport]], [[Liverpool John Lennon Airport]], [[Manchester Airport]], [[Leeds Bradford Airport]], [[Robin Hood Airport Doncaster Sheffield]] and [[Bristol Airport]]. Some train services ran with revised timetables. Trains in Kent were delayed for up to three and a half hours, with hundreds of travellers left stranded. In late December, [[Eurostar]] trains from Paris or [[Brussels]] towards [[St Pancras railway station|St. Pancras station]] were [[Eurostar#Snowfall consequences|severely delayed]], with delays of up to 16 hours.{{cite news|title = Passengers trapped on Eurostar trains relive ordeal|publisher =BBC News|date=19 December 2009|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8422305.stm|accessdate = 7 January 2010}} All Eurostar services were cancelled from 19–21 December; delays and service cancellations continued after that.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurostar.com/UK/uk/leisure/customer_care/questions_answers.jsp |title=– Questions and Answers |publisher=Eurostar|date= |accessdate=9 January 2010}} Buses on the [[Isle of Wight]], [[Gloucester]] (skeleton service was being run in [[Gloucester]] during Wednesday 6 January) and across southern [[Hampshire]] were suspended on 5 January owing to heavy snowfall, leaving a large number of people stranded. Limited services were back in operation on 7 January in [[Southampton]] and [[Portsmouth]] on the mainland and between [[Newport, Isle of Wight|Newport]] and the other main towns on the [[Isle of Wight]]. All services in [[Gosport]], [[Fareham]], [[Locks Heath]], [[Titchfield]], [[Whiteley]] and [[Warsash]] areas were suspended and remained so for two days because of road conditions. As of 8 January, one service was running between [[Gosport]] and [[Fareham]] and one between [[Fareham]] and [[Southampton]] (although this service was unable to serve Locks Heath or Titchfield). The [[A3 road|A3]] and the A3(M) around [[Horndean]] and the [[Hindhead]] area and the [[A1 road (Great Britain)|A1]] experienced disruption; many minor roads were closed and only the main motorway and A-road network were passable for much of 5, 6 and 7 January. In [[North East England]] the A1(M) and A19 suffered challenging conditions (mainly in the evenings and at night) as a result of temperatures dropping to well below zero Celsius. Bus service between Newcastle and Sunderland experienced some disruption, as local operators suspended services but the [[Tyne and Wear Metro]] was an alternative which was only subject to delays due to the temperatures. ==={{anchor|Roads and buses|Trains}}Ireland=== Local and minor roads were severely affected. [[Dublin Airport]] closed on Wednesday, 6 January{{cite news|url=http://news.eircom.net/breakingnews/17075655/?view=Standard |title=Dublin Airport closed until at least 8pm |publisher=Eircom.net |date=6 January 2010 |accessdate=7 January 2010 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} and again on Friday, 8 January. [[Cork Airport]] closed on Sunday, 10 January at 6:30 pm and did not reopen until 12:30 pm on Monday, 11 January.{{cite news|url= http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/0111/breaking10.htm|title= Munster feels brunt of Cold weather as Cork Airport opens after 18hours of closure|publisher= The Irish Times|date= 11 January 2010|accessdate= 11 January 2010}} [[Dublin Bus]] temporarily cancelled all services,{{cite news|url=http://news.eircom.net/breakingnews/17075398/ |title=All Dublin Bus services halted |publisher=Eircom.net |date=6 January 2010 |accessdate=7 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100109031220/http://news.eircom.net/breakingnews/17075398/ |archivedate=9 January 2010 |df= }} and [[Ireland West Airport Knock]] also closed.{{cite news|url= http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/knock-airport-closed-441052.html|title= Knock airport closed|publisher= Breaking News Ireland|date= 7 January 2010|accessdate= 7 January 2010}} All schools were ordered to close for a day on Monday 11 January, due to the snow. Dublin's tram service [[Luas]] was badly affected; most drivers and bus riders were afraid to travel on the ice-covered roads. ==={{anchor|Trains|Snow removal}}Finland=== Long-distance railway traffic to and from [[Helsinki]] halted between 19 and 22 February. Cold weather, blizzards and drifting snow blocked 300 rail switches at the Ilmala rail yard, making traffic impossible. More than half the long-distance trains were cancelled, leaving hundreds of Lapland-bound winter holiday travellers stranded at [[Helsinki railway station|Helsinki Central Railway station]]. Trains which were not cancelled ran several hours late. The amount of [[Snow removal|snow cleared]] from [[Helsinki]] streets and transferred to [[snow collection site]]s was 210,000 truckloads.{{Cite journal |title=Helsingin lumitalkoissa on rikottu kaikki ennätykset |author=Jenita Sillanpää |journal=[[Helsingin Sanomat]] |date=6 March 2011 |url=http://omakaupunki.hs.fi/paakaupunkiseutu/uutiset/helsingin_lumitalkoissa_on_rikottu_kaikki_ennatykset/ }} ==={{anchor|Norway|Trains|Sweden}}Norway and Sweden=== Rail transport in Norway and Sweden experienced serious setbacks throughout this Winter. ==={{anchor|Airports}}Spain=== Heavy snowfall in the [[Catalonia]] region during March 2010 led to cancellation of [[Ryanair]] flights to and from [[Girona Airport]] on 9 March. === Economic impact === Winter vegetable crops such as [[cauliflower]] and [[potatoes]] were threatened by the icy temperatures, and harvesting of carrots, [[turnip]]s, [[sugar beet]] and [[parsnip]]s was delayed since the fields are frozen.{{cite news | author = Doward, Jamie | title = Britain counts the cost of big freeze | work = The Observer | date =10 January 2010 | pages = 8–9 | url =https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/jan/10/no-let-up-big-freeze | accessdate = 12 January 2010 | location=London}} The harsh winter was estimated to cost the [[economy of the United Kingdom]] [[GBP|£]]700 million.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8447873.stm|title=Frozen Britain: The cold snap in numbers|publisher=BBC News|date=8 January 2010|accessdate=10 January 2010}} A new British record for natural gas consumption reached {{convert|454000000|m3}} on 7 January, according to the [[National Grid (UK)|National Grid]]. Approximately 12,000 schools were closed across the United Kingdom. A drop in about 30% of UK retail sales was estimated, with uneven consequences;{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8450426.stm|title=Cold snap sees retail sales plunge|publisher=BBC News|date=10 January 2010|accessdate=10 January 2010}} pubs, out-of-town shopping centres and department stores were worst affected. Local-store sales and the sale of sledges, cat litter and contraceptives increased. The [[Scottish Highlands]] saw a boost to tourism and [[winter sports]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8450560.stm|title=Snow gives Scottish economy a boost|publisher=BBC News|date=10 January 2010|accessdate=10 January 2010}} The [[Cairngorms]], near [[Aviemore]], received its best business since the 1970s as thousands of tourists visited the area. ===Sporting events cancelled=== The snowfall in January postponed [[Association football|football]] games in the English [[The Football League|Football League]], [[Premier League]], [[Football League Cup]]{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8441786.stm |title=Carling Cup semis postponed as freeze continues |work=[[BBC Sport]] |publisher=[[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=5 January 2010 |accessdate=5 January 2010}} and the [[FA Cup]]. There were further postponements in Scotland (with 15 football matches postponed on 2 January),{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8436366.stm |title=Only two Scots games beat freeze |work=[[BBC Sport]] |publisher=[[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=2 January 2010 |accessdate=5 January 2010}} and in [[Serie A]], [[Serie B]], [[Lega Pro Prima Divisione]], [[Lega Pro Seconda Divisione]] and [[Serie D]] Italian football matches. Football in Northern Ireland was also affected.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/northern_ireland/8445792.stm |title=Weekend sport hit by big freeze |work=[[BBC Sport]] |publisher=[[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=8 January 2010 |accessdate=10 January 2010}} In [[rugby union]], there were cancellations in the [[2009–10 English Premiership (rugby union)|English Premiership]], [[2009–10 Celtic League|Celtic League]], the [[All-Ireland League (rugby union)|All-Ireland League]], the [[2009–10 Top 14 season#Rounds 16 to 20|Top 14]],{{cite press release|url=http://www.lnr.fr/omm/upload/CP_080110_report_Bourgoin_Bayonne_J18.pdf |title=Report du match CS Bourgoin-Jallieu / Bayonne |language=French |publisher=Ligue Nationale de Rugby |date=8 January 2010 |accessdate=8 January 2010}} a [[2009–10 Heineken Cup pool stage#Pool 4|Heineken Cup fixture]] in Brussels scheduled for 19 December,{{cite web|url=http://www.ercrugby.com/eng/12_12929.php |title=Stade Français Paris v Ulster Rugby |publisher=European Rugby Cup |date=20 December 2009 |accessdate=8 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100417190314/http://www.ercrugby.com/eng/12_12929.php |archivedate=17 April 2010 |df= }} and a [[2009–10 Heineken Cup pool stage#Pool 2|Heineken Cup fixture]] in [[Newport, Wales|Newport]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ercrugby.com/eng/12_12924.php |title=Newport Gwent Dragons v Biarritz Olympique Pays Basque |publisher=European Rugby Cup |date=19 December 2009 |accessdate=8 January 2010}} Other affected sports included [[Gaelic football]]'s [[O'Byrne Cup]], [[Dr. McKenna Cup]], [[McGrath Cup]] and FBD League games. The [[field hockey]] [[Irish Junior Cup (men's hockey)|Irish Junior Cup]] also saw postponements. ==See also== {{Portal|weather}} {{Commons category|Winter of 2009–2010 in Europe}} *[[March 2010 North American winter storm]] *[[2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat wave]] *[[2009 North American blizzard]] *[[Arctic dipole anomaly]] *[[Climate of Europe]] *[[Global storm activity of 2009]] *[[Global storm activity of early 2010|Global storm activity of 2010]] *[[North Atlantic drift]] *[[Polar vortex]] *[[Siberian High]] *[[February 2009 Great Britain and Ireland snowfall]] *[[Winter of 1990–1991 in Western Europe]] *[[Winter of 2010–2011 in Europe]] == References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Cold wave}} {{DEFAULTSORT:European Winter Storms Of 2009-10}} [[Category:2009 in Europe]] [[Category:2009 in Ireland]] [[Category:2009 disasters in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2009 meteorology]] [[Category:2010 in Europe]] [[Category:2010 in Ireland]] [[Category:2010 disasters in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2010 meteorology]] [[Category:Cold waves in Europe]] [[Category:Weather events in Ireland|Winter]] [[Category:Cold waves in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Winter weather events|2009–10 in Europe]]

{{multiple image |align=right |direction=horizontal |total_width=400 |image1=Young stellar objects in the Rho Ophiuchi cloud complex.jpg |width1=3500 |height1=2800 |caption1=YSOs in the [[Rho Ophiuchi cloud complex]] |image2=A young star takes centre stage.jpg |width2=1280 |height2=1284 |caption2=V1331 Cyg, a YSO surrounded by a reflection nebula }} {{Star formation}}
'''Young stellar object''' ('''YSO''') denotes a star in its early stage of evolution. This class consists of two groups of objects: [[protostar]]s and [[pre-main-sequence star]]s.
==Classification by spectral energy distribution== A star forms by accumulation of material that falls in to a protostar from a [[circumstellar disk]] or envelope. Material in the disk is cooler than the surface of the protostar, so it radiates at longer wavelengths of light producing excess infrared emission. As material in the disk is depleted, the infrared excess decreases. Thus, YSOs are usually classified into evolutionary stages based on the slope of their [[spectral energy distribution]] in the mid-[[infrared]], using a scheme introduced by Lada (1987). He proposed three classes (I, II and III), based on the values of intervals of [[spectral index]] <math>\alpha \,</math>:<ref name="Lada1987">{{cite book |chapter=Star Formation: From OB Associations to Protostars |title=Star Forming Regions: Proceedings of the 115th Symposium of the International Astronomical Union Held in Tokyo, Japan, November 11–15, 1985 |publisher=D. Reidel |location=Dordrecht |first=Charles J. |last=Lada |editor1-first=Manuel |editor1-last=Peimbert |editor2-first=Jun |editor2-last=Jugaku |pages=1-17 |date=1987 |bibcode=1987IAUS..115....1L |isbn=978-90-277-2388-8}}</ref>
<math>\alpha=\frac{d\log(\lambda F_\lambda)}{d\log(\lambda)}</math>.
Here <math>\lambda \,</math> is wavelength, and <math>F_\lambda</math> is [[Luminous flux|flux]] density.
The <math>\alpha \,</math> is calculated in the wavelength interval of 2.2–20 <math>{\mu}m</math> ([[near-infrared|near-]] and [[mid-infrared]] region). Andre ''et al.'' (1993) discovered a class 0: objects with strong submillimeter emission, but very faint at <math>{\lambda}<10{\mu}m</math>.<ref name="Andre1993">{{cite journal |title=Submillimeter Continuum Observations of <math>{\rho}</math> Ophiuchi A: The Candidate Protostar VLA 1623 and Prestellar Clumps |journal=The Astrophysical Journal, Part 1 |first1=Philippe |last1=Andre |first2=Derek |last2=Ward-Thompson |first3=Mary |last3=Barsony |volume=406 |issue=1 |pages=122-141 |date=March 1993 |doi=10.1086/172425 |bibcode=1993ApJ...406..122A}}</ref> Greene ''et al.'' (1994) added a fifth class of "flat spectrum" sources.<ref name="Greene1994">{{cite journal |title=Further Mid-infrared Study of the <math>{\rho}</math> Ophiuchi Cloud Young Stellar Population: Luminosities and Masses of Pre-main-sequence Stars |journal=The Astrophysical Journal, Part 1 |first1=Thomas P. |last1=Greene |first2=Bruce A. |last2=Wilking |first3=Philippe |last3=Andre |first4=Erick T. |last4=Young |first5=Charles J. |last5=Lada |volume=434 |issue=2 |pages=614-626 |date=October 1994 |doi=10.1086/174763 |bibcode=1994ApJ...434..614G}}</ref>
*'''Class 0''' sources – undetectable at <math>{\lambda}<20{\mu}m</math> *'''Class I''' sources have <math>{\alpha}>0.3</math> *'''Flat spectrum''' sources have <math>0.3>{\alpha}>-0.3</math> *'''Class II''' sources have <math>-0.3>{\alpha}>-1.6</math> *'''Class III''' sources have <math>{\alpha}<-1.6</math>
This classification schema roughly reflects evolutionary sequence. It is believed that most deeply embedded Class 0 sources evolve towards Class I stage, dissipating their [[circumstellar envelope]]s. Eventually they become optically visible on the [[stellar birthline]] as pre-main-sequence stars.
Class II objects have circumstellar disks and correspond roughly to classical [[T Tauri star]]s, while Class III stars have lost their disks and correspond approximately to weak-line T Tauri stars. An intermediate stage where disks can only be detected at longer wavelengths (e.g., at <math>24{\mu}m</math>) are known as transition-disk objects.
==Characteristics== YSOs are also associated with early star evolution phenomena: [[astrophysical jet|jet]]s and [[bipolar outflow]]s, [[Astrophysical maser|masers]], [[Herbig–Haro object]]s, and [[protoplanetary disk]]s (circumstellar disks or proplyds).
==Classification of YSOs by mass== These stars may be differentiated by mass: Massive YSOs, intermediate-mass YSOs, and [[brown dwarf]]s.

'''Zel'dovich mechanism''' is a chemical mechanism that describes the oxidation of nitrogen and [[NOx|NO<sub>''x''</sub>]] formation, first proposed by the Russian scientists [[Yakov Borisovich Zel'dovich]], [[David A. Frank-Kamenetskii]] and P. Ya. Sadovnikov in 1947.<ref>Zeldovich, Y. A., D. Frank-Kamenetskii, and P. Sadovnikov. Oxidation of nitrogen in combustion. Publishing House of the Acad of Sciences of USSR, 1947.</ref><ref>Williams, Forman A. "Combustion theory". (1985).</ref><ref>Zeldovich, I. A., Barenblatt, G. I., Librovich, V. B., Makhviladze, G. M. (1985). Mathematical theory of combustion and explosions.</ref> The reaction mechanisms read as
:<chem>{N2} + O <->[k_1] {NO} + {N},</chem> :<chem>{N} + O2 <->[k_2] {NO} + {O},</chem>
where <math>k_1</math> and <math>k_2</math> are the reaction rate constants in [[Arrhenius law]]. The overall global reaction is given by
:<chem> {N2} + {O2} <->[k] 2NO.</chem>
The overall reaction rate is mostly governed by the first reaction (i.e., [[Rate-determining step|rate-determining reaction]]), since the second reaction is much faster than the first reaction and occurs immediately following the first reaction. At fuel-rich conditions, due to lack of oxygen, reaction 2 becomes weak, hence, a third reaction is included in the mechanism, also known as '''extended Zel'dovich mechanism''' (with all three reactions),<ref>Lavoie, G. A., Heywood, J. B., Keck, J. C. (1970). Experimental and theoretical study of nitric oxide formation in internal combustion engines. Combustion science and technology, 1(4), 313–326.</ref><ref>Hanson, R. K., Salimian, S. (1984). Survey of rate constants in the N/H/O system. In Combustion chemistry (pp. 361–421). Springer, New York, NY.</ref>
:<chem>{N} + {OH} <->[k_3] {NO} + {H}.</chem>
The forward [[rate constant]]s of the reactions are given by<ref>{{cite web |url=http://web.eng.ucsd.edu/mae/groups/combustion/mechanism.html |title=San Diego Mechanism}}</ref> :<math>\begin{align} k_{1f} &= 1.47\times 10^{13} \, T^{0.3} e^{-75286.81/RT},\\ k_{2f} &= 6.40\times 10^9 \, T e^{-6285.5/RT}, \\ k_{3f} &= 3.80\times 10^{13}, \end{align}</math> where the [[pre-exponential factor]] is measured in units of cm, mol, s and K, temperature in [[kelvin]]s, and the [[activation energy]] in cal/mol; ''R'' is the [[universal gas constant]].
==NO formation== The rate of [[Nitric oxide|NO]] concentration is given by
:<math>\frac{d[\mathrm{NO}]}{dt}= k_{1f} [\mathrm{N}_2] [\mathrm{O}] + k_{2f} [\mathrm{N}] [\mathrm{O}_2] + k_{3f} [\mathrm{N}] [\mathrm{OH}] - k_{1b} [\mathrm{NO}] [\mathrm{N}] - k_{2b} [\mathrm{NO}] [\mathrm{O}] - k_{3b} [\mathrm{NO}] [\mathrm{H}].</math>
